The pastries are fresh and tasty and the dark roasted coffee is the best in the Haight. This quaint little shop is a must see for yourself. I won't go anywhere else.
author: Kevin S.

description:
SO, If you wan't to see the most beautiful barista in town, be welcomed by the enveloping and unparalleled warmth of the wonderful Tamar and Vasquin, cozy up with Marilyn Monroe, Audrey Hepburn or Frank Sinatra (reincarnated caffeinated clones of them) and indulge in SF's finest coffee-based concoctions, THIS is where you want to go!!!  Leave all your worries behind when you step through the doors of Cantata Coffee and discover yourself immersed in a magical Middle Eastern-influenced oasis where each cup truly is made with love.  I can't speak highly enough about this place, I'm salivating just thinking about it.  

Also, you can't miss it, just look for the psychedelic sidewalk chalk art in front of the store, produced by local Haight/Ashbury artist/legend who goes by the name of Spaz.  If you're really lucky, you just might catch a glimpse of him in action; unleashing his artistic advertisements on the ground right before your eyes. ;-)  

Keep your eyes equally peeled for Juliet atop the interior balcony and watch out for Romeo behind the counter. ;-)

Shukran Cantata Coffee!
author: Paul C.

description: Great masala chai. I'm kind of a chai connoisseur. I've had the chai at many Indian restaurants, cafés, and at Raman's in half moon bay. I like it the best at Cantata. It's on the spicy side so if you like it sweet you should add a sweetener. The owner is very friendly, she always remembers me. The cookies are fresh. The powdered almond cookie is delish.
author: Kathy H.

description:
This coffee spot is such a gem - located right in the middle of busy Haight St. Both customer service and quality of coffee go above and beyond, and each trip into this cozy, yet beautiful spot create a great experience. I frequent Cantata for a cup of coffee (as I am often in the area) and am greeted each and every time with warmth, friendliness, and kindness. The staff and baristas have a special way of treating all customers with familiarity and make them feel at ease amidst all the craziness of the Haight. The couple who own the cafe are lovely, and genuinely take interest in their customers, making sure their experience is enjoyable and pleasant. They are such kind and gentle people, and create an environment very unique to Cantata.

Although I normally order only a cup of coffee, it is difficult for me to even consider sampling any of the other cafes on Haight St. Their coffee is rich and delicious, and always brewed very hot. I often find my cup of coffee to be one of the biggest comforts in my day. I have also sampled their vanilla latte and famous "Audrey Hepburn" - both tasty treats that complement the wide variety of pastries sold at the register. I highly recommend any of the muffins, the banana nut bread, and especially the granola cookies. All three are equally dangerous and sooo good!

If you are looking for a cup of coffee in a uniquely comfortable environment, I highly suggest Cantata. Their creative, delicious drinks paired with their kind and genuine staff make it an ideal spot for a caffeine fix!
author: Hannah B.

description:
meh nothing special coffee was ok and service was ok.

compared to some of the great coffee shops ive been to in san francisco this place just doesn't stack up.

like i said the coffee is basic, nothing special and the service was ok.


nothing that would make me come back
author: Jaime D.

description:
Bad bad bad. I ordered a small Earl gray which was supposed to be 1.75. I asked for whole milk in it, became 3.75. Gave cashier a 5. Got back 25 cents.

First of all: REALLY? You're going to charge me 3.75 for a small cup of tea and milk?! Second of all: that was a TEABAG. Third of all: I just bought the entire box of teabags for you. And lastly, learn how to do math. 

Don't get me wrong, they are definitely friendly people. But probably because she just robbed me of 4.75.
author: Bianca W.

description: I had a delicious cup of coffee.  Also had some lemon gelato that hit the spot on a hot day in San Francisco.   The place is a good place to go.  Overall a good place to be.   Next time is boba time.
author: Sosi K.

description: Very poor coffee. Ordered a soy latte, and it was 20 mins before it was cool enough to drink. Seriously way to hot which ruins the coffee. Super loud traffic outside with the door left open, had to shout my order at the poor ladies behind the counter. The staff seemed sweet enough, but the place has a poor layout with no real direction where to order or stand once you have. Not going again.
author: Kathryn R.

description:
This is one of the most pleasant little shops in a cute neighborhood filled with tons of annoying people.  The pot smokers will puff in your face, the wannabe hippies will say stupid things about "Nirvana" to me and the hipsters rant about occupying Wall Street as they pull out the latest iPhone from their Prada bags.  

I'm relieved that I was able to escape to this tiny little coffee shop.  It didn't try to be fake trendy by having a Devanagari font/scripted sign.  All I wanted was a nice Italian soda without someone pretending to know about Indian culture or what occurred in the 1960's.  I know plenty enough about that already.  Luckily, the girl working there was focused on her job and made sure to ask me if I needed more syrup and less ice.  Tamara, who is super friendly, talked to me about where I'm from, and we exchanged life stories.  It's great that the place is under new management.  It has made a huge difference in the quality of service.  They have also added more spots to sit, as that was really needed the first time I visited.  

If you want a bakery with the highest quality items, you probably will not get them here.  It doesn't have the best almond croissant in town.  However, I wanted to escape all of the pretentious jerks who frequently congregate the Haight-Ashbury area.  I got exactly what I needed for next to nothing and have returned a few times just to pop in and say hello.  The young musician who works there is really friendly as well.  Lots of patrons become regular customers.  I'm glad that some of the control freaks who drink way too much coffee didn't like the place.  Don't come back.  Go home and boss your children around, soccer moms.  As for that girl who completely understands wanting to up sell items after being asked where the restroom is, yet bashes Tamara for saying "Enjoy your walk" as she leaves: I hope you feel better about yourself for giving Cantata one star.  I have serious doubts that you're important enough for Tamara to be intentionally rude to you.  She's so nice to everyone who walks in.  Regardless, I'm sick of people assuming that every place is a public restroom...
author: Jay P.

description:
The place is quaint, looked as though it served as an entry or mudroom in the Victorian it is built into.  Didn't meet the old guy, met a cute, helpful barista chick, who clued me in on the espresso milkshake ($4.75) after I was turned down at another coffee joint on the other side of the street.  Kinda small portion size, but chocked with caffeine goodness, it's the perfect beverage for those of us who still straddle the line between adulthood and childhood.
Extra * for having Philippine Brand Guava and Mango juice!  Last place I'd think to see that stuff.
author: Sam N.

description: Some people have a genuine interest in making other peoples' days better. Its the little things that count, like a friendly conversation with a new or recurring face. The few times I've been to this quaint little cafe, I've left not only with a yummy caffeine fix, but I've also left appreciating warmhearted folks like Tamara who go above and beyond. I highly recommend stopping in and checking it out!! Oh and try the gelato!
author: Samantha L.

description: Looks like this place gets a lot of mixed reviews. I have only been there once, but my experience was nothing short of ideal. I was on my way to the bluegrass festival and stopped in for an espresso real quick. The girl at the counter was that informative, but she was cool and made good conversation. Luckily the man who I assume owns the place was there to talk to me about there espresso. Apparently the man's friend roasts there beans, and has been doing it for 45 years. The espresso was excellent, good flavor, good crema, and well extracted. They were even nice enough to show me the beans they use and talk a little bit about them. I had a great experience there, and if you love espresso I would highly recommend you check them out.
author: John S.

description:
This quaint little place feels like straight out of the movie chocolat.

The interior is warm and cozy with a cool selection of coffee, tea and pastries. I had a,marylin monroe, and it sure did live up to its name :)

But the best part was the barista (Tamar) herself, who makes it a point to make every customer feel special
author: Sebastian M.

description:
I usually don't review a place based on bad service, but I'm making an exception here. Without a doubt the rudest barista I've ever experienced - I don't ever remember someone telling me to "come on, use your brain" while trying to order coffee.

I couldn't wait to get home to burn this place, but was rewarded to find the number of 1-star reviews and references to this woman's mental instability. Instead of being pissed, now I just feel bad for her. 

Avoid this place at all costs! Coffee to the People and People's Cafe are just down the street.
author: eliah g.

description: Good Coffee for a walk around historic Haight area.
author: R H.

description: Definitely decent coffee at a decent price.  The ladies are also very nice and friendly.  The guy- not so much.
author: Anthony G.

description: I was discharged from Davies Medical Center two days ago after being treated for chest pains. Since the cafés near DMC were packed, I decided to drive us to the Haight, where my partner had not been over 20 years. We discovered Cantata, a small Armenian café, as we strolled around looking for a quiet place.  No invasive background music. Patrons can have quiet conversations.  Good coffee, Middle Eastern pastries, and fabulous hospitality from  Tamar and husband,  Vasker. My partner and I are both old men with difficult health issues. We love celebrating life together, while we still can.Cantata provided  us  another reason to do it.   Prices are reasonable. We give it five stars, and hope  it never becomes  yuppiefied.
author: George W.

description: In all of my 12+ years in San Francisco, this is by far the best coffee I have ever had!
author: jen b.

description: The new owners are absolutely outstanding! They have changed that whole vibe to family and friendly!  Great coffee and great people.
author: sarah g.

description: I love Cantata. Such a cute, quaint respite from the bustle of Haight. I go there sometimes to kill time before work and the owners are always super sweet and nice to talk to. They have great espresso and it's usually warm inside with big windows that are just perfect for people watching on Haight St... which is always interesting of course since the neighborhood is littered with..uhhum.. characters shall we say. They even have yummy gelato! Which is why I give this place 5 stars!
author: Danielle R.

description:
I went in about a month after the new management started. They warmly greeted me, and were very happy in general, which is a nice change! I felt so welcomed, naturally I tried multiple pasties which were all quite nice and very inexpensive, and the coffee which was great also. They even let me use the staff restroom after I had stayed to chat for a little while!

Definitely worth going to regularly for some baklava and a coffee!!!!
author: Jonathan F.

description: Eh, the mocha I ordered was alright.  Nothing special.  Wasn't bad, but wasn't very good either.  Not good enough to make me want to go back.  But a bit cutesy inside.  They serve nice looking pastries, though I didn't taste any.  And whipped cream on your drink is 50 cents extra- boooooo
author: A T.

description: I was there for the first time the owner who runs the place is so friendly they have the best coffee and worth trying their pastries . THANK GOD FOR NEW OWNERSHIP !!!!!!!! VERY INVITING PLACE !!!! MUST STOP BY...
author: GS S.

description:
New Management makes a huge difference!!! 

Wife and I were walking the little guy on Haight street on Sunday when we decided to get a cup of coffee from this place.  The husband and wife team were friendly, attentive, and kind. My cappuccino and my wife's hot chocolate were both perfect, and the homemade baklava was off the hook. The place is clean and the location is nice (at the beginning of Cole). 

I read some of the other reviews about this place and was a little surprised by all the negativity but I guess they were in regards to the old owners/operators. The new management makes a huge difference and I would highly recommend this place to others.
author: Mike Y.

description: Not that great of a coffee place and being next to Good Will doesn't help. The flavor is really lacking, but I just got a regular cup of joe. I do hope that their specialty stuff is much better.
author: M C.

description: Overpriced, dingy, disorganized staff (are three people behind the counter at any given time really necessary?) I didn't expect much; after all it is the Haight but I gave it a shot anyways. It is the kind of place where if you want half and half, they give it to you only when you ask and when you do they hand you a pint of Lucerne that they probably bought at Safeway on the way in and look eager to get it back lest you suddenly find an urge to over-milk your coffee. Aside from that - no debit cards taken and the coffee itself makes it all not worth the trouble. Hopefully their new management can help clean things up. I am fan of small businesses, but no one in any type of economy is happy giving up hard-earned money for low quality products.
author: Vanessa M.

description: I had the Audrey Hepburn, which was delicious. I also bought a pound of the house blend beans, which were not so delicious. The owner was very friendly and I will definitely return if I'm ever in SF again!
author: Mark L.

description:
This coffee house has been in the neighborhood for ages but I've never stepped in there or even remotely had the urge to get a coffee from there. Why? Not sure exactly, but the shop itself isn't exactly inviting plus there are so many other coffee houses around the neighborhood itself. 

I was waiting the bus on Haight and Cole one morning and haven't got my coffee yet. It was the closest one so figured 'why the hell not?' I agree with Netty, the owner is very friendly and pleasant. His shop is neat and simply decorated. The coffee is well priced and the small size I found to be a perfect size! 

The second time I went there, I was trying to branch out and tried the pastries. Boy, what was I thinking?! I got this Raspberry Croissant and it was stale! It was hard. Did I miss a sign saying it's a day old (or even 2!) pastries? I don't think so. I will stay away for sure from all pastries!!

Maybe one of these days, I will try the ice cream.
author: Perry S.

description:
I like this place ... I find it clean, sweet, aesthetically pleasing and I absolutely adore the older gentleman behind the counter.  

For those that are up on my reviews know that I am seriously not a huge fan of haight street itself ... I'm not nor have I ever been into the hippie shit, I have little tolerance for slow (read: stoned) walkers, i find the smell of resale shops exceptionally nauseating, I am offended by teenagers that pose as homeless while their cellphones ring and of course, the dress over jeans look is about as common sense as ugg boots sans the snow ... you can see why I avoid the main drag of haight street since these repulsive visions make the usual stroll an exceptionally unpleasant one.  However, this little cafe is too sweet to ignore ... so when I crave the perfect nonfat, sugarfree vanilla latte, I force myself out the door to brave the brutal elements of haight street en route to this destination ... and those that know me know that this is truly extending high and mighty props.
author: Sarah K.

description: I ordered a soy mocha latte. She scooped some Nesquik powder into some hot soy milk with not-so-gourmet coffee. Oh, hell to the no!
author: Patricia S.

description: Absolutely love this place!! Great coffee and great owner, Tamar, who reminds me of everyone's mom or favorite aunt. My brother and I are from Washington D.C. and every time we go to Haight, we are sure to visit her and her shop. She serves the Best cinnabuns ever! Also the best Audrey Hepburn I have ever had.
author: Jon S.

description: Really good, unique coffee choices with star names like Audrey Hepburn and Frank Sinatra. my favorite is the green tea latte, uncommon and delicious. The staff is really nice & if you cuy 6 coffees the next one is free.
author: Genna M.

description: Almost all the coffee in the upper haight stinks, except for this place. I  trolled the streets when I worked there looking for a good cup of strong, full bodied coffee. The coffee here is delicious, and comes in attractive plain white paper cups. The old man who owns the cantata is jovial and pleasant. He always brightened my early morning retail details. They roast all their own coffee, and there's never a line.
author: Netty L.

description:
We spotted this place while waiting for a friend who was doing some shopping.  The coffee was not bad.  The service a little gruff.  For us, our experience was just blase.  Nothing to write home about and nothing to get really ticked about.  Would I come here again no!  

Our issue with this place is not so much the place itself as the young lady working behind the counter.  She was a bit curt with us, but I can deal with that.  Just not visit again.  What she did to another customer blew me away.  Another out of towner who was waiting to head down to get her tattoo at one of the shops in the neighborhood had just set her stuff down at the adjoining table.  She even greeted us and before she could do anything else, the young lady came from behind the counter and demanded of us if the other woman was with our group.  Before we could answer she told the other woman that the tables out front were for customers only.  The woman asked her to give her a moment and held up her asthma inhaler.  The barista then went into the store and told her she only had 2 minutes or she would be calling the police.  The poor woman decided to go into the store to purchase something to keep the barista happy.  Our friend had joined us by then and followed her in the store and watched in amazement as the barista refused to serve her and told her too late she had called the police.  Needless to say we were amazed and prepared to defend this poor woman.

Now I understand that yes there are those who loiter and create a scene but this was not the case.  This lady was also a tourist like us and was prepared to buy a drink and a pastry to keep the barista happy.  She refused to sell her anything and just told her she could deal with the police.  This whole incident happened in a matter of less than 10 minutes.  

We will not be visiting this establishment again.  Which is sad, because it is very likely that the owner of ths potentially (especially from reading the reviews) cool place may not realize what a problem they have on their hands.  This woman definitely should not be working in any capacity with the general public or customer service. 

Food decent.  Staff (from our experience) sucked!
author: Michele P.

description:
One of the few good cups of coffee in the city.  
Not only do you get a cup of coffee for a dollar and a half, you also get to talk to your own Italian Grandpa.
author: Patrick A.

description: It's not fair that this place has been tarnished with a low star rating from the previous management who sold the business a year ago. I usually skipped this place because it doesn't have the best seating, but now it has become my main coffee shop. The drinks are good and prices are extremely reasonable. A large iced coffee is only 2-3 dollars, depending on the barista ; ) Every single employee who works here is extremely nice and fun to talk to. The owners are very nice and all of their staff is really hip and friendly. Give it a try the next time you're in the neighborhood. Shoutout  to Alex, who knows to give me an orange straw to match my sunglasses
author: John N.

description:
I really wish I had checked in with my fellow Yelpers before stopping by this place. I also wish I could give zero stars.

Our unbelievable story goes like this: We were seduced by Cantata's outdoor tables, not because of their makeshift quality--the furniture is crowded, irregularly-sized and uncomfortably cheap--but because it was just a beautiful day to enjoy the fresh air. I left my colleague outside at an open table (there's only 2), and walked inside to order. Since it took both of the women behind the counter to help the 1 customer ahead of me, and since neither was willing to even acknowledge my presence, I decided to head back outside to check if this place even had the wifi that we needed. After 60 seconds of trying to figure it out (in which I never sat down, and instead stood facing the window so I could spot an available barista), one of the women came outside. INSTEAD OF APOLOGIZING FOR THE WAIT and taking our order, she immediately demanded that we leave--no, she actually shooed us off like we were animals, saying that the tables are for customer only. When my colleague explained that we were coming in to order (and even though we were reflexively gathering our belongings to comply with her wish), she actually used her short stout body like a broom to move us as quickly as possible out of the space. And then, get this: SHE FLIPPED US OFF.

Seriously?! Why work in the service industry if you don't like people?! Friends, don't let Cantata take your money, time or good mood.

(And, not that it should matter: We were nicely dressed. There was no reason to suspect hat we had no money, nor that we may be shady characters.)
author: Savannah L.

description:
I am mad that I even have to give them a star. I walked in there yesterday before a meeting with my boss. As we walked to the counter we could hear one lady snapping at the last customer as she walked out. We pony up to the counter and Boss orders a Cafe ole I ordered a black tea to which she replied in a evil tone "Which one"  I said the darkest you have. she said what size? I said large please. Having worked in a coffee house usually you get 2 tea bags in a large that is why it is usually more expensive. Boss asked "why is the large so much more?" She said because it is a large. you pay for more everything. I said you are paying for an inch of water Half joking half not. She started in on me and snapped more and Boss said FINE WE DON"T NEED YOUR F"ING COFFEE. She stood there and said get out then.
We went across the street to get another coffee in a bit of disbelief and mentioned it to the other cashier to which she replied that she hears that often.

I will not be going back there ever again.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
I'm a little surprised at the positive reviews here.  I've been here 3 or 4 times and it is hands down the worst coffee on Haight.  That's pretty damning.  I'm talking drip and espresso.  

I'm tempted to give them a second star since they were the only coffee shop open on xmas, but they lose half of it because I couldn't finish the cup because it was so nasty.

They lose the other half because of the annoying tourists.  One star!
author: Dan G.

description:
This weekend my lovely, friendly, warm boyfriend sat down outside to wait for me to finish at the Wells Fargo atm.  I wanted that extra 45 seconds to decide what drink to order from Cantata.  Some how in that time span (I'm serious it was not more than one minute--I even used the fast cash option at the atm), the woman behind the counter at Cantata came outside, told him to leave, and placed what I assume is a fake call to the police.  I came back to find him pale as a ghost and saying, "Ma'am I'm giving you nothing but love right now.  I wish you a peaceful day."  She kept her back to us.  

Now, I'm sure she gets bothered a lot by people wanting to sit in those chairs.  But even if she has a problem with loiterers--he was wearing a tie and jacket and I was on my way to a United Way event so I had nice clothes on too.  We were clearly customers.  WTF.  Open your mind to the idea that not everyone is your enemy, lady.  What a horrible, scary place to buy a cup of coffee.
author: Meghan C.

description: I live a minute up the street and I try to get my coffee here before school or work every morning. Vaskin, Hanada and everyone that works here make it such an enjoyable experience, they're the friendliest cafe on the block BY FAR, they're a great addition to the wonderful community feel of Haight. In addition to all of those warm fuzzies, their coffee is great. I've tried a ton of stuff over the year and it's all delicious. My favorite are the oat bars (fresher and chewier than most!) and blended green tea. Definitely stop in if you're looking for a place in the neighborhood, and take a seat to people watch through the window or chat up the wonderful staff!!!
author: Katy G.

description: Caffeine addicts will find flavored coffees, lattes, mochas, and espresso drinks, while health fiends can indulge in freshly-squeezed juice choices like carrot, cantaloupe, and watermelon, or thick fruit smoothies.
author: Gourmet G.

description: I went in here and got a scoop of Double Rainbow ice cream. Halfway through, the ice cream got gooey, like it does when ice cream is old and sits out too long. I went back in to ask for a partial replacement for the gooey ice cream and the woman in there got some serious attitude. She told me she wouldn't replace it so I asked for my money back, so she snatched it from me and gave me my money back. Don't go there: the ice cream was bad and the service was terrible.
author: Rachel K.

description: I agree with Netty L that "almost all the coffee in the upper haight stinks," but I don't find Cantata to be an exception to the rule.   I've had the coffee here three times, and the last two just because I was trying to be fair and give it another chance.  The ice cream is ok, though, and I like that they exist.  But they really need to get some better coffee.  If you are down that end of Haight, I think I would go with Rockin Java.  Neither place has good tasting coffee, but at least Rockin Java's coffee is organic and fair trade.  Better yet, get a little exercise and walk down to Coffee to the People -- Organic, fair trade, and delicious.
author: John D.

description: I walked in the other morning. The barrista (generous) looked like she needed a shot of Prozac lumbered down the ladder from a loft and muttered something that just made me think twice about spending my $ here. So I turned around and walked out. The place looked dirty. So far, I am disappointed in the cuisine and cafes on Haight. Doesn't anybody take pride in their shops? The entire street could use a serious power washing. I guess I'll stick with People's Coffee for now. I am used to the quality of Java Beach across from the Zoo.
author: Eileen M.

description: Not the best coffee, but it does the trick for late evenings at work, and mostly I just really love the sweet Iranian owner who asks how I am doing and actually means it...
author: Janine M.

description: I got a decent Americano here. That's all for me. It was decent but nothing to write home about. My fiancé, on the other hand, had what he calls, "the best coffee in the entire WORLD!" He is a girly-man and loves the sweet stuff--and Cantata delivers. His cappuccino/latte thing-a-ma-jig was very delicious. I'd even order it for myself as a treat, given the right occasion. It was sweet, yummy delicious-ness, but not any more than it needed to be. Plus, the lady behind the counter was nice and completely shocked when fiancé offered to restock the cup lids. What can I say? I dig the humble people like myself.
author: Katie P.

description: Rockin' Java (try the house blend) & Coffee To The People has much better coffee.
author: Maria D.

description: Coffee wasn't anything exceptional, but loved the old guy behind the counter. Hard of hearing, but super friendly. Only time I've ever been offered to have the chocolate and cinnamon sprinkles put on my latte for me. And he refilled his nonfat Double Rainbow yogurt. Thanks man!
author: Jason B.

description: Coffee is a difficult thing to buy on Haight Street. Since I drink a lot of it, I end up at Coffee Cantata quite a bit. The ladies that run the place are always nice to socialize with, but the drinks aren't exactly the top quality. A size small is REALLY a small, comparable to a short cup over at Starbucks. Their espresso is pretty fair though. Seating is limited, but is spacious enough to sit and people watch for a while.
author: Taylor S.

description: so amazing sweetest people ever!!! and I had the best peach smoothie ever!!! oh & my best friend loved her iced coffee!!! :)
author: Lena C.

description: This is a very small coffee shop right on Haight street.  They have a few chairs outside and some seats at a window bar, good for people watching on the weekend.  I love the older guy who works here, he's very sweet and makes a mean espresso.  Their smoothies and milkshakes are great as well, and I recommend trying some of the little chocolates under the glass dome if you get a coffee.
author: Simon B.

description: The sign says "milkshake or malt, thick and dangerously creamy". The shake was anything but. Watery and icy would be more accurate. It's unfortunate, because the ladies are pretty nice compared to the dickweeds at Cafe Cole. I strongly dislike the upper haight for food and beverage. Doesn't anyone realize that all the restaurants and cafes cater to tourists, and therefore don't have to worry about repeat business? That's why everything is sub par. Grrrr. Makes working here tough.
author: Hale B.

description: What a change the new management has made!!!!! As of the 1st of February, new management has blessed this coffee shop. The new owners are a nice family and the women on the counter (believe her name is Tamara) is super nice!!! She is very warm, welcoming and made me the best cappuccino. The previous owners destroyed this place (reason for all the other negative reviews) but I am so glad the new owners are picking up the pieces and making this coffee shop a happy place to walk into! I have found my new coffee joint and will continue going there, as long as the owners decide to stay put! I will highly recommend this place for all who need a quick coffee/pastry fix! I do admit, it is the best coffee on Haight street.  Thank you Cantata Coffee and to the new happy owners! :)
author: Nadia V.

description: Wow, worst coffee ever. Maybe one step up from 7-11. Complete waste of money.
author: Kristen W.

description: i went here today and ordered an espresso shake, the description sounded great. so 10 or so minutes later she puts it on the counter for me and my girlfriend notices they forgot the whipped cream so she asks for some and the woman dissappears into the back and comes out with a can and says in a russian accent it will be 50 cents. i point at the description that clearly lists whipped cream as one of the ingredients on their sign and she won't turn to look she says it's extra. i said would you please look at your sign and she says it's not included. i said you know last time i was in here there was a guy giving you a hard time and i thought, oh poor girl, but now i'm pretty sure you deserved it. she just stared blankly and said her boss told her to charge for whipped cream. on top of it the $5 drink was filled to the top with chipped ice. it really sucked.
author: john b.
